subject: RE: [junit] JUnit Anti-patterns

messageBody:
With all the recent (in the last decade) activity in developer-written
tests, conventions for effective tests are still forming. I think these
kinds of discussions are valuable for synthesizing divergent experiences.
Here are my thoughts on the issues raised below.

Re: multiple asserts. One of my goals for tests is that they point precisely
to the problem when they fail. If I have many asserts in one test,
especially if the assertions are interspersed with calls to the objects
under test, then I run the risk of having a failing test that requires
considerable investigation before I can see what went wrong. OTOH, I haven't
found it useful to deliberately limit myself to a single assertion per test,
as is the practice of some list members.

Re: code that throws exceptions. I prefer to declare the test case as
throwing the exception. I haven't ever had trouble debugging from the
information provided in the exception. Discarding that exception and getting
a generic AssertionError seems a step backwards to me.

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Cédric Beust ?
> Sent: Tuesday, February 21, 2006 12:54 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] JUnit Anti-patterns
>
> Hi Joe,
>
> Joe Schmetzer wrote:
> >
> > >I've just updated the JUnit Anti-patterns page I maintain at
> > >http://www.exubero.com/junit/antipatterns.html. I'd be
> interested in
> > >any feedback, if people want to suggest additions or improvements.
>
>
> I don't really understand this:
>
> This is a design decision that permeates JUnit, and when you decide to
> report multiple failures per test, you begin to fight against JUnit.
>
> I don't see how having more that one assert "fights against"
> JUnit (what
> does this even mean?) and in the code that I see every day,
> very few tests
> contain only one assert. Especially if your tests require
> two or three
> statements to set up in the test method (not in setUp()), in
> which case
> there is even more to be gained to run more than one assert
> so you don't
> have to duplicate this code in other test methods.
>
> Also, the fix you show in your documentation is simplistic.
> What if the
> code to be extracted is specific to that test method? If you
> move it to
> setUp(), you are suddenly charging *all* the other test
> methods of that same
> class with this set up cost that they have no need for.
>
> Also, it seems to me your recommended pattern for code that
> must throw an
> exception ("don't catch it and declare the exception in the throws
> statement") goes against common practice. Plus, it will
> cause JUnit to
> report an Error instead of a Failure, although this distinction is
> thankfully going away with JUnit4.
>
> A more common way to address this problem is to catch the
> exception and do a
> fail().
>
> Other than that, your guide is fine advice.
>
> --
> Cédric
